Overwatch 1 was one of the greatest games ever made. It introduced us to new characters that to this day I love and adore. Millions of players, this was their first introduction to an fps. The game required noone to play a character that could aim. It was a wonderful bonding experience as well and the community was extremely wholesome.

Heres where we get to Overwatch "2" if you can even call it that. It's more like Overwatch 1.5
Blizzard has become a money hungry, battle pass, pay 25 dollars for a skin mess. The whole reasoning for Overwatch 2 was that it was going to have a story mode. The story mode was completely scrapped and replaced by "story missions". 3 years, it was THREE YEARS of no content for the first Overwatch with the promise of something greater.

The company that was well respected, Blizzard, is gone. Activision Blizzard, is now known for sexual harassment, silencing players for the free Hong Kong movement, unfinished games, and micro transactions.

I miss Blizzard. I miss Overwatch. I still love the characters, but I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

Overwatch is the greatest first-person shooter ever made, and my all time favorite game. Before I get into in my review I'll preface my review by letting the reader know that there is basically a review bombing campaign against the game, and while I never agree with review bombing, I understand the anger of the fanbase when it comes to their intentions by giving the game a negative review. I still strongly disagree with review bombing as a practice as reviews should be about the game itself, and not the drama or monetization practices within it (especially when those monetization practices don't affect gameplay in anyway). 

I'm going to split my review into multiple segments so you can better understand the various aspects of the game. I'll start first with monetization.

[h1] Monetization [/h1]

Whenever a video game has microtransactions there are always going to be naysayers and skeptical players, and rightfully so as greedy, money-hungry developers do everything in their power to part players from their money. Overwatch 1 had extremely fair monetization in the form of lootboxes. Overwatch was a paid game that cost below the industry standard at $40, with a more expensive "Legendary" version with bonus skins included at $60. Throughout the year Overwatch would host six seasonal events. These events were Lunar New Year, Overwatch Archives, Anniversary, Summer Games, Halloween Terror, and Winter Wonderland. With each of these events there was a new Arcade game mode introduced with lighthearted gameplay to pull you away from the main game. Along with these events came time-limited lootboxes with various cosmetics for each character, these included skins, highlight intros, emotes, victory poses, voicelines, sprays and player icons. Overwatch 2 has since added player titles, name cards, souvenirs, and weapon charms. At the time people thought that lootboxes were predatory, and at the time I disagreed. If you played the game enough, you could easily get the event items. You could purchase one lootbox for $1 dollar, or a larger amount for a discounted price. Each lootbox would have 4 items, and during the three week-long event you would earn event-themed lootbox. Every event lootbox would have at least one event item. This mechanic did NOT work well during the first year of Overwatch considering that there would be duplicate items in each lootbox. One year into Overwatch's lifespan they got rid of duplicate items in lootboxes, unless no more items of a certain rarity were available to earn. If you received a duplicate item you earned currency based on the rarity of the item. Each lootbox had at least 1 "rare" item.  [url=https://i.imgur.com/1HSjtRR.png]You can see the break down of the currency values with this chart.[/url] So this lootbox system was an incredibly easy to earn mechanic, and all items could be earned in game except for special skins like the annual Blizzcon event skin ($40-$50) or Overwatch League skins which require you to watch YouTube to farm the currency. 

So this lootbox mechanic was the primary way to earn items in Overwatch 1, and it lasted from 2016 until 2022. It was an insanely fair mechanic that had its detractors, but it honestly worked. If you played the game you could easily earn the time-limited event items. The quickest way to do this would be to earn all of the default non-event cosmetics so that your event lootboxes wouldn't have a chance to give those default items. It took a bit of time to earn all of the items in the default pool, but it was honestly doable since there were a considerable more amount of event items.  That's how this mechanic functioned.

So Overwatch 2 comes out in Early Access in October 2022 as a Free-To-Play game with extremely predatory practices in terms of earning cosmetics. I'll start with what is NOT a predatory practice, in my mind. Each season has a Battlepass that last 60 days. These Battlepasses contain 9 skins, with some cosmetics of every type. Introduced with the Battlepass system is a new rarity of skin called "Mythic" that allows you to customize the Mythic skin to your liking, with a lot of variance. This is an AMAZING value at $10. Where they lose me a bit is that there are premium Battlepass bundles that contain exclusive skins not found anywhere else, and these can be pretty pricey at $30-$40 (I think the $40 Battlepass is exclusive to Season 6 which includes PvE missions, so I assume the price will return to $30). These bundles are simply expensive, especially if the player is spending $30-$40 every 2 months. Regardless of this premium Battlepass bundle, at $10 the Battlepass system is fun, and a steal. Now this is where Blizzard shows their disgusting greed. Each season has a theme, like Season 1's Cyberpunk theme for example. There is a cosmetic store that will rotate weekly store exclusive skins at a VERY high price. Each one of these store skins can cost up to $20, but have been cheaper when bundled, although that isn't entirely common. Recently there has been a bundle of Season 1 skins that were DRASTICALLY cheaper than each skin's individual price, but still a little bit pricey, and that's with the bundled discount that many games with a microtransaction store have. This is simply unacceptable as the once earnable skins are now locked behind a store...but it gets worse. The skins that you could earn from lootboxes for free are also now locked behind a paywall as well in the premium store. This is and was a disaster but there have been mild attempts from Blizzard to walk it back. Starting with Season 3 each Battlepass gives 1,500 Overwatch 1 Credits for use on Overwatch 1 cosmetics. This is a really small amount, and not really feasible for players who would want to earn mutliple years-old cosmetics from Overwatch 1. They have effectively made all skins only earnable from the new paid currency "Overwatch Coins". Players who earned Credits from lootboxes during their time playing Overwatch 1 can still spend that currency, but can't use it on items that cost "Overwatch Coins". I know that's a bit confusing, but the long haul of it is that Blizzard is making older skins inaccessible to newer players. This is the reason a great game has been review bombed, and there's a part of me that understands that. The economy for this game is out of whack, and it really bothers me that they're essentially locking off a way to earn items outside of smaller events that give usually an "Epic" rarity skin, or the Battlepass. You can also do weekly challenges that during the course of a 2-month long season give about 540 Overwatch Coins. These weekly missions require a fair amount of gameplay, and progress your Battlepass levels...but here's the kicker. Doing all of these nets about 540 Overwatch Coins, but skins can cost upwards of 2,200 Overwatch Coins...so you don't even have enough to cover a Battlepass purchase of 1,000 Overwatch Coins. I'm not really sure how else I can explain this disaster of monetization, but hey there it is. All of these practices do not involve the gameplay, but it's still a really big bummer and bane to gamers that once loved playing Overwatch, especially in the golden era of unlocks being 2016-2022.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Редко пишу обзоры на игры, но хочу высказаться по поводу Overwatch 2. Если ты играл когда-то в обычный Overwatch, то ситуация которая происходит на данный момент в игре, будет для вас вопиющей и не справедливой. Но если ты новый игрок, который знает про Overwatch только то что, там крутые синиматики, или что-то подобное, для вас эта игра покажется очень не плохой. Без условно, раньше можно было получать бесплатные скины, в достаточно большом количестве, но и сейчас в игре, за бесплатную цепочку БП, можно получить 1500 валюты, за которую можно спокойно купить легендарный скин, для своего персонажа. Оправдывает ли этот то что забрали кейсы и способ фарма скинов? конечно нет, хороший ли это вариант для новичков, получить крутой скин для своего мейна? Да. без условно, поступок Близарт в отношение старых игроков это позор, но новички не знаю это-го, и для них, игра будет и в правду хорошо.

I've been playing Overwatch since it was Overwatch 1 on Battle.net back in 2016. I would definitely recommend the game to anyone. I also like the fact that it's on steam now, no more having multiple launchers for my games.

那時候是2016年，我看到雙龍的預告，那句「龍が我が敵を喰らう」把我拉進了鬥陣特攻的世界。
跟幾個好朋友說了介紹了這個遊戲，優良的動畫輕鬆地拉了朋友入坑，花了1900元買了典藏版，讓我有了小小的虛榮感。
進遊戲之後，玩了半藏，幾場過去，比起射箭，我似乎更會被箭射到，幾場下來箭沒射到幾支，爬牆的能力倒是增加了不少。
源式就更不用說了，最常講的台詞就只有「I need healing」跟「龍神の剣を阿#$@&*」。
後來只好放棄了這兩個帶我入坑的角色開始練習了其他角色。
死神、攔路豬、托比昂到我最愛的炸彈鼠，這些角色貫穿了我的鬥陣生涯
到後面為了打贏雙飛練的76；為了讓自己有大範圍控場而學的小美，鬥陣特攻帶給我就像毒品般的快樂。
每一次的活動跟模式，我跟朋友都會激烈的討論，從一開始的路西歐足球，玩到後面變成前500，跟朋友一起幻想後面的夏季運動會的所有可能，暢談路西歐足球的美好，「如果路西歐足球出現在自訂該有多好」我對朋友這樣說著。鼠肯斯坦、冬境樂園、新春、捍衛密令、鬥陣對決、還有周年活動，每一個活動剛推出的時候，都是我們廢寢忘食的開始。
一年過去了，我們還是在期待最新的英雄什麼時候出，最新的動畫那最高品質的呈現。但英雄從一開始的三個月一隻，變成了有出就不錯了。而活動也是，跟朋友討論了無限可能的夏季運動會，籃球、躲避球、跑酷最後都只存在我們的期望中，夏季運動會是一個改了路西歐技能的路西歐足球。其他活動也不例外，本來以為到了下一次就會有新的內容，但每一次最新的往往只有排山倒海的造型。
英雄的失衡；303的出現；強制222；PVE英雄模式的取消；一代遊戲幣的不轉移，到最後，朋友已經各奔東西，沒有人肯留在這個地方了。而現在路西歐足球也真的出現在了自訂了，但好像一切都為時已晚了。我也只是在這，祭奠我的過去。

我將我的青春、最快樂的那個我、一同與這個遊戲埋葬於此。願你的靈魂去到更好的地方，變得更好。

As someone who played the original Overwatch beta all those years ago and bought it on release (even got the physical origins edition) its sad to see the state the game has been left in. Overwatch 1 was a great game for probably about its first two years and then Blizzard went really hard into competitive and esports when the game is the most fun in a casual environment. Then they decided to kill Overwatch 1 for this sequel which is really nothing more than a larger sized update. They have added basically nothing new except micro-transactions and questionable balance changes. Sadly they have also removed any sort of way to play the original. I hope one day fans can make some sort of way to play Overwatch 1 in its early years again. 

At least Mei is still cute.

Prepare to the story people!

Once upon a time there was a dev studio called Blizzard that was praised for the quality of their games, then they created a game that was a sucessor for TF2 and was a blast, everyone loved but that's when everything started to go sour. When they announced Overwatch they promised a pve / pvp game and many people really wanted to play both, but because of the popularity of the pvp they discarded the pve and all the ideas that made many join this game were just forgotten.

For  years overwatch was one of the greatest arena shooters but because of many bad decisions of the developing team the game was losing its own beloved player base, with numbers going down they announced a new game, yes a SECOND OVERWATCH! People got hyped, old promises were renewed, things that they said were going to be on the first game would appear in the second! The comunity was hyped until the release of the so called OVERWATCH 2.

What a disappointment, the game was the same with one less hero at each team, old maps recycled and few new additions to this "new game", but people still have faith that one of the most expected contents would be available, unfortunately it was not. The game was released without a pve....again, but the promise was there, then months passing, skins recycled, a battle pass that don't reward enough those who buy, not even letting they buy the pass again if they complete, stagnant the game start to lose players again.

THEN THE UNEXPECTED! not really....they announced that the pve mode was discarded to not even a month after the statement bring a really bad pve mode that people need to PAY separately to play it and now with the player going down more and more they released the game on steam in hopes that people play more and pay their ridiculous products and etc.

The end.
